title: Will AP champions have a larger panoply of items in pre-season Riot?
body:
There's never been an issue of AP being generally weak. 

It's just that AP isn't that great. AD items are in a huge variety but AP is a bit dull.

how about just increasing the price of crit itemization? and some price reductions on ap items?

marksmen 3 item core builds right now are {{item:3031}} {{item:3087}} {{item:3094}} are 500 to 1000 gold cheaper than the 3 item builds of other carry classes.

is there a specific reason why a **lategame**, and item scaling class of champions has cheaper items and power spikes sooner off the same amount of gold as mages, bruisers and assassins who are supposed to have the most game impact by midgame?

{{item:3071}} {{item:3053}} {{item:1001}} {{item:3742}} = 9400 gold

{{item:3089}} {{item:1001}} {{item:3165}} {{item:3102}} = 10000 gold

{{item:3147}} {{item:3142}} {{item:3814}} {{item:1001}} = 9200 gold

{{item:3031}} {{item:3046}} {{item:3087}} {{item:1001}} = **8900 gold**

how does this make sense to anyone on your balance team?

an its not like marksmen items are less slot efficient than these other builds. they power spike earlier off cheaper itemization and from there on out keep outscaling other classes.

why are people suprised that other lanes cant ever carry against a marksman when marksmen get comparable power spikes off less gold, and from there on out just keep outscaling other carries?

there are two ways to deal with the current situation imo. either increase the price of zeal items straight up by 300 gold and make marksmen take longer to scale again. (and no stat increases this time! just a straight up nerf to zeal items. marksmen are already outshadowing everyone on 5 items. they dont need to scale later and harder, they just need to scale later)

or reduce 5 item build effectiveness on marksmen. they get to power spike around the same time as other carries, but dont get to outscale everybody anymore. one option would be to nerf infinity edges crit damage passive and slight reductions to the stats on zeal items to make their cheap price justifyable. this would also solve the problem of marksmen outbursting mages and assassins with crit streaks on their auto attacks.
Those are some odd combinations you listed there...

theyre really not. theyre representative.

marksmen core builds right now are infinity edge and two zeal items. it doesnt matter which zeal item you chose. theyre all the same price. warlords bloodlust compensates for the lack of lifesteal in their builds.

you can replace the dead mans for any other armor/health item which all cost 2900 gold, or {{item:3065}} visage on the bruiser build which would reduce the total price by 100 gold, or replace cleaver with {{item:3078}} which would increase the price by 700 gold.

for mages you could replace the banshees with another ap item like {{item:3157}} which would end 100 gold cheaper, but still 1000 gold more expensive than a 3 item marksman build.

for assassins you could replace the edge of night with either {{item:3156}} or {{item:3074}} or {{item:3812}} . in those cases the total price of the build would increase by several 100 gold.


you can vary these builds around a little bit, but the point im trying to make is clear. the standart 3 item marksman build for carries like {{champion:18}} {{champion:96}} {{champion:29}} right now is several 100 gold  to a 1000 gold cheaper than comparable builds of other classes. which causes them to hit their power spikes a lot sooner than these other types of carries.

why do you think a 3/0 marksman carries games harder around midgame than a 5/0 mage or top laner right now? support protection and tank peel add onto the problem, but marksmen itemization in itself is overtuned.

The ap one isn't. Name me a single champion besides Veigar that takes Deathcap as a first, second, or even third item unless they're already 30/0. If you replaced deathcap with void staff that would be closer. Maybe replace banshee's with a Liandry's. 

I agree with you that ADC itemization is too cheap, but it seems for ap like you were just picking the most expensive items.

{{item:3089}} {{item:3165}}  for mages is a comparable power spike to {{item:3031}} and a completed {{item:3086}} item.

the combination is not odd. it is THE marksman ad core item compared to THE mage ap core item.

{{item:3031}} crit damage passive is a multiplier to the marksmans critical strike chance and ad, the same way {{item:3089}} passive is a multiplier to the mages ap off his items.

you would never rush death cap and buy it around 3rd item if you pick it up. in most cases your first item would be morellos. but the reason mages arent buying deathcap at all right now is exactly because its so expensive that delays their 3 item power spike too much.

3 seasons ago, deathcap was picked up as frequently on mages as infinity edge on marksmen. and the item had the same passive back then as it does now. it was sometimes even built as a first item rush on mages who were snowballing in their lane.


replace {{item:3089}} with {{item:3285}} in a mage core build and youre STILL paying several 100 gold more than a marksman does for his 3 item power spike.


{{item:3285}} {{item:3165}} {{item:3157}} is still 9000 gold compared to {{item:3031}} + double zeal 8600 gold.

from there on you can keep going with penetration items. {{item:3135}} 2650 gold vs. {{item:3036}} 2600 gold. it doesnt get any better.


now if were regarding the fact that marksmen just keep scaling from there on out as the game progresses, and mages start falling off, then it shouldnt be a surprise that marksmen are overbearing at the moment.


mages, assassins and bruisers used to power spike at around 15 to 20 minutes and had their own game phases where they had the most game impact up to around 30 minutes where they started to fall off.

marksmen used to become relevant around 25 to 30 minutes where they started to outscale these other carries.

right now marksmen are just power spiking sooner and scaling harder, and a major reason is that their itemization is just way cheaper than it should be.
The fact that no champion can pick deathcap earlier than 5th item is the problem we are trying to discuss here.

Where have you been for the past two months?

Burst mages aren't much different from AP assassins really.
The reason why AP items work for such a big general group of champions is because many of them share the basic mage trait - scale off AP and do more damage. There's some variety to builds (scaling mages, mpen for assassins, Gunblade and a bit spellvamp) but overall, the core is the same.

The same could be said for AD champions, who all scale off AD and do more damage. However, we have options for AD marksmen, assassins, fighters, etc., yet AP mages, assassins and fighters all still share largely the same item pool. When juggernauts got updated, only AD itemization changed for them, and when assassins got a rework, only AD assassins got their special stat made for them. There has been a clear and consistent imbalance in the way the two stats have been addressed in itemization, and large-scale changes to classes that featured both AP and AD champions catered exclusively to AD itemization, to the detriment of AP champions: not only is their itemization less diverse, often champions are pushed to buy items with stats that they shouldn't really have, namely AP assassins getting durability off of Protobelt, Gunblade, and Zhonya's. There isn't a large enough body of items to support, say, tanky AP builds in the same respect as tanky AD builds, and it's not even that easy to go for a full damage squishy build either, as most AP items tend to go for a middle-of-the-road approach and offer a bit of health or resists in addition to AP and CDR. It's not a great state of affairs, and there isn't really that much making AP a special case relative to AD in how more or less deserving AP users are of diverse itemization.

Because the AD champions play highly differently. An assassin has absolutely no need for AS, nor really any need for crit or lifesteal. Marksmen (generally) prefer AS and Crit to lethality. Juggernauts take items like {{item:3071}}. Bruisers might take a mix of any of these.

{{item:3147}}, {{item:3085}}, and {{item:3071}} are all nothing alike. Meanwhile, {{item:3089}} can be used by just about any AP user. {{item:3165}} gives the exact same useful stats for {{champion:105}} as it does {{champion:103}}.

Sure, but AP fighters play very differently from AP assassins, who play differently from mages. As said above, an AP fighter would love a heavy AP + health item, but that's not really something an AP assassin wants, and the many manaless AP champions don't really want to opt into the mana-heavy itemization of mages. We also see several marksmen pick Duskblade and Black Cleaver (an item that's popular on assassins as well, so it really is universal), and when Lethality was released it was heavily co-opted by marksmen when it was successful (this still happens, too), so AD itemization isn't really as super-distinct as it's made out to be.

There have also been many occasions, which persist today, of AP champions experiencing legitimate problems from their lack of item diversity: AP fighters often struggle to get tankiness and damage at the same time, and when they could with Rylai's, the item was so over-statted and generic that it had to be nerfed, as it was also being used by mages. Assassins who want to go for flat pen with Haunting Guise are railroaded into building a) health, a stat they don't really want to prioritize spending gold on, and b) Liandry's, a DoT item that doesn't really help their burst in the best way. Whereas even squishy AD champions can easily purchase life steal and make use of it (via Death's Dance or Ravenous Hydra, for example), AP champions have no major sustain option besides Catalyst of Aeons (exclusive to mana champions) and Gunblade (which is mostly bought by assassins for its burst active). AP champions play just as differently as AD champions, and also want very different stats based on their class, yet they're still being forced to contend with a much smaller pool of items, many of which cover multiple functions instead of just one (Morellonomicon is notorious for this, which is why it's essential to most AP builds).
